title: Japan's big manufacturers' sentiment at 6-year low
text:
TOKYO--Sentiment among Japan's large manufacturers deteriorated to the weakest level in more than six years in the three months to September amid growing trade tensions and the slowdown in China and other Asian countries, a central bank survey showed Tuesday.

The main index measuring large manufacturers' sentiment was at plus five in the July-September period, compared with plus seven in the previous June survey, according to the Bank of Japan's quarterly tankan survey.

The index represents the percentage of companies saying business conditions are favorable minus those saying conditions are unfavorable.

The reading was the lowest since June 2013, although it was higher than the forecast for plus two from a poll of economists by data provider Quick.

The deterioration will likely add pressure to the Bank of Japan to ease monetary policy further when its policy board meets on Oct. 30-31. Gov. Haruhiko Kuroda has said the bank would thoroughly examine economic conditions at the next meeting and take additional measures "without hesitation", if necessary.

Tuesday's results showed Japanese companies weren't very confident about the outlook. Large manufacturers expect the headline index to drop to two in the next three months, while non-manufacturers forecast it would deteriorate to 15 from 21 in the September survey, reflecting caution against the impact of the national sales tax increase to 10% from 8%, which went into effect Tuesday.

Large companies also grew cautious about their investment plans. They plan to increase their capital investment in the current fiscal year ending in March 2020 by 6.6%, compared with an increase of 7.4% projected three months ago.

Write to Megumi Fujikawa at megumi.fujikawa@wsj.com
